a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "A 1 = 2"
and h1 : "A 7 = -2"
and h2 : "B 1 = -2"
and h3 : "B 7 = 2"
and h4 : "\<forall> i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> C i = 2 * cos ((7 - i) * pi / 7)"
and h5 : "\<forall> i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> sqrt ((A i - C i)\<^sup>2 + (B i - C i)\<^sup>2) = abs (2 * sin (i * pi / 7))"
shows  "(\<Prod> i = 1..6. sqrt ((A i - C i)\<^sup>2 + (B i - C i)\<^sup>2)) = 28672"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $A$ and $B$ be the endpoints of a semicircular arc of radius $2$. The arc is divided into seven congruent arcs by six equally spaced points $C_1$, $C_2$, $\dots$, $C_6$. All chords of the form $\overline {AC_i}$ or $\overline {BC_i}$ are drawn. Find the product of the lengths of these twelve chords. The final Answer is 28672
 ### Proof
 Let $\omega = e^{2 \pi i/14}.$  We can identify $A$ with $2,$ $B$ with $-2,$ and $C_k$ with the complex number $2 \omega^k.$ [asy] unitsize (3 cm); int i; pair A, B; pair[] C; A = (1,0); B = (-1,0); C[1] = dir(1*180/7);
 C[2] = dir(2*180/7); C[3] = dir(3*180/7); C[4] = dir(4*180/7); C[5] = dir(5*180/7); C[6] = dir(6*180/7); draw(A--B); draw(arc((0,0),1,0,180)); for (i = 1; i <= 6; ++i) {   draw(A--C[i]--B);   dot("$C_" + string(i) + "$", C[i], C[i]);
 } dot("$A$", A, E); dot("$B$", B, W); [/asy] Then $AC_k = |2 - 2 \omega^k| = 2 |1 - \omega^k|$ and \[BC_k = |-2 - 2 \omega_k| = 2 |1 + \omega^k|.\]Since $\omega^7 = -1,$ we can also write this as \[BC_k = 2 |1 - \omega^{k + 7}|.\]Therefore, \[AC_1 \cdot AC_2 \dotsm AC_6 = 2^6 |(1 - \omega)(1 - \omega^2) \dotsm (1 - \omega^6)|\]and
 \[BC_1 \cdot BC_2 \dotsm BC_6 = 2^6 |(1 - \omega^8)(1 - \omega^9) \dotsm (1 - \omega^{13})|.\]Note that 1, $\omega,$ $\omega^2,$ $\dots,$ $\omega^{13}$ are all roots of $z^{14} - 1 = 0.$  Thus \[z^{14} - 1 = (z - 1)(z - \omega)(z - \omega^2) \dotsm (z - \omega^{13}).\]One factor on the right is $z - 1,$ and another factor on the right is $z - \omega^7 = z + 1.$  Thus, \[z^{14} - 1 = (z - 1)(z + 1) \cdot (z - \omega)(z - \omega^2) \dotsm (z - \omega^6)(z - \omega^8)(z - \omega^9) \dotsm (z - \omega^{13}).\]Since $z^{14} - 1 = (z^2 - 1)(z^{12} + z^{10} + z^8 + \dots + 1),$ we can write
 \[z^{12} + z^{10} + z^8 + \dots + 1 = (z - \omega)(z - \omega^2) \dotsm (z - \omega^6)(z - \omega^8)(z - \omega^9) \dotsm (z - \omega^{13}).\]Setting $z = 1,$ we get \[7 = (1 - \omega)(1 - \omega^2) \dotsm (1 - \omega^6)(1 - \omega^8)(1 - \omega^9) \dotsm (1 - \omega^{13}).\]Therefore, \begin{align}
 &AC_1 \cdot AC_2 \dotsm AC_6 \cdot BC_1 \cdot BC_2 \dotsm BC_6 \\ &= 2^6 |(1 - \omega)(1 - \omega^2) \dotsm (1 - \omega^6)| \cdot 2^6 |(1 - \omega^8)(1 - \omega^9) \dotsm (1 - \omega^{13})| \\ &= 2^{12} |(1 - \omega)(1 - \omega^2) \dotsm (1 - \omega^6)(1 - \omega^8)(1 - \omega^9) \dotsm (1 - \omega^{13})| \\
 &= 7 \cdot 2^{12} \\ &= \boxed{28672}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "A 1 = 2"
and h1 : "A 7 = -2"
and h2 : "B 1 = -2"
and h3 : "B 7 = 2"
and h4 : "\<forall> i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> C i = 2 * cos ((7 - i) * pi / 7)"
and h5 : "\<forall> i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> sqrt ((A i - C i)\<^sup>2 + (B i - C i)\<^sup>2) = abs (2 * sin (i * pi / 7))"
shows  "(\<Prod> i = 1..6. sqrt ((A i - C i)\<^sup>2 + (B i - C i)\<^sup>2)) = 28672"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem:
Given the functions A, B, and C on real numbers defined as follows:

A(1) = 2, A(7) = -2
B(1) = -2, B(7) = 2
C(i) = 2 * cos((7 - i) * π / 7) for 1 ≤ i ≤ 6

Further, it is given that for each i between 1 and 6 (inclusive), the expression sqrt((A(i) - C(i))^2 + (B(i) - C(i))^2) equals the absolute value of 2 * sin(i * π / 7).

Find the product of sqrt((A(i) - C(i))^2 + (B(i) - C(i))^2) for all i from 1 to 6. The final answer is 28672.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes r :: real and A B C :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "r = 2"
and h1 : "\<forall>i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> C i = r / 7 * i"
and h2 : "\<forall>i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> A (C i) = sqrt (r powr 2 - (C i) powr 2)"
and h3 : "\<forall>i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> B (C i) = sqrt (r powr 2 - (r - C i) powr 2)"
shows  "(\<Prod>i = 1..6. A (C i) * B (C i)) = 28672"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $A$ and $B$ be the endpoints of a semicircular arc of radius $2$. The arc is divided into seven congruent arcs by six equally spaced points $C_1$, $C_2$, $\dots$, $C_6$. All chords of the form $\overline {AC_i}$ or $\overline {BC_i}$ are drawn. Find the product of the lengths of these twelve chords. The final Answer is 28672
 ### Proof
 Let $\omega = e^{2 \pi i/14}.$  We can identify $A$ with $2,$ $B$ with $-2,$ and $C_k$ with the complex number $2 \omega^k.$ [asy] unitsize (3 cm); int i; pair A, B; pair[] C; A = (1,0); B = (-1,0); C[1] = dir(1*180/7);
 C[2] = dir(2*180/7); C[3] = dir(3*180/7); C[4] = dir(4*180/7); C[5] = dir(5*180/7); C[6] = dir(6*180/7); draw(A--B); draw(arc((0,0),1,0,180)); for (i = 1; i <= 6; ++i) {   draw(A--C[i]--B);   dot("$C_" + string(i) + "$", C[i], C[i]);
 } dot("$A$", A, E); dot("$B$", B, W); [/asy] Then $AC_k = |2 - 2 \omega^k| = 2 |1 - \omega^k|$ and \[BC_k = |-2 - 2 \omega_k| = 2 |1 + \omega^k|.\]Since $\omega^7 = -1,$ we can also write this as \[BC_k = 2 |1 - \omega^{k + 7}|.\]Therefore, \[AC_1 \cdot AC_2 \dotsm AC_6 = 2^6 |(1 - \omega)(1 - \omega^2) \dotsm (1 - \omega^6)|\]and
 \[BC_1 \cdot BC_2 \dotsm BC_6 = 2^6 |(1 - \omega^8)(1 - \omega^9) \dotsm (1 - \omega^{13})|.\]Note that 1, $\omega,$ $\omega^2,$ $\dots,$ $\omega^{13}$ are all roots of $z^{14} - 1 = 0.$  Thus \[z^{14} - 1 = (z - 1)(z - \omega)(z - \omega^2) \dotsm (z - \omega^{13}).\]One factor on the right is $z - 1,$ and another factor on the right is $z - \omega^7 = z + 1.$  Thus, \[z^{14} - 1 = (z - 1)(z + 1) \cdot (z - \omega)(z - \omega^2) \dotsm (z - \omega^6)(z - \omega^8)(z - \omega^9) \dotsm (z - \omega^{13}).\]Since $z^{14} - 1 = (z^2 - 1)(z^{12} + z^{10} + z^8 + \dots + 1),$ we can write
 \[z^{12} + z^{10} + z^8 + \dots + 1 = (z - \omega)(z - \omega^2) \dotsm (z - \omega^6)(z - \omega^8)(z - \omega^9) \dotsm (z - \omega^{13}).\]Setting $z = 1,$ we get \[7 = (1 - \omega)(1 - \omega^2) \dotsm (1 - \omega^6)(1 - \omega^8)(1 - \omega^9) \dotsm (1 - \omega^{13}).\]Therefore, \begin{align}
 &AC_1 \cdot AC_2 \dotsm AC_6 \cdot BC_1 \cdot BC_2 \dotsm BC_6 \\ &= 2^6 |(1 - \omega)(1 - \omega^2) \dotsm (1 - \omega^6)| \cdot 2^6 |(1 - \omega^8)(1 - \omega^9) \dotsm (1 - \omega^{13})| \\ &= 2^{12} |(1 - \omega)(1 - \omega^2) \dotsm (1 - \omega^6)(1 - \omega^8)(1 - \omega^9) \dotsm (1 - \omega^{13})| \\
 &= 7 \cdot 2^{12} \\ &= \boxed{28672}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes r :: real and A B C :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "r = 2"
and h1 : "\<forall>i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> C i = r / 7 * i"
and h2 : "\<forall>i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> A (C i) = sqrt (r powr 2 - (C i) powr 2)"
and h3 : "\<forall>i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> B (C i) = sqrt (r powr 2 - (r - C i) powr 2)"
shows  "(\<Prod>i = 1..6. A (C i) * B (C i)) = 28672"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem:
Given a real number $r = 2$, and three functions $A$, $B$, and $C$ defined as follows:

- For every integer $i$ from $1$ to $6$, $C(i) = \frac{r}{7} * i$.
- For every integer $i$ from $1$ to $6$, $A(C(i)) = \sqrt{r^2 - (C(i))^2}$.
- For every integer $i$ from $1$ to $6$, $B(C(i)) = \sqrt{r^2 - (r - C(i))^2}$.

Find the product of all values of $A(C(i)) * B(C(i))$ for $i$ from $1$ to $6$. The final answer is $28672$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B :: "real * real" and C :: "int \<Rightarrow> real * real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 6 \<Longrightarrow> dist A (C i) = dist B (C i) = 2"
and h1 : "\<forall>i j. 1 \<le> i \<and> i < j \<and> j \<le> 6 \<Longrightarrow> dist (C i) (C j) = 2 * sin (pi / 7)"
and h2 : "dist A B = 2 * sqrt 2"
shows  "product (\<lambda>i. dist A (C i) * dist B (C i)) {1..6} = 28672"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $A$ and $B$ be the endpoints of a semicircular arc of radius $2$. The arc is divided into seven congruent arcs by six equally spaced points $C_1$, $C_2$, $\dots$, $C_6$. All chords of the form $\overline {AC_i}$ or $\overline {BC_i}$ are drawn. Find the product of the lengths of these twelve chords. The final Answer is 28672
 ### Proof
 Let $\omega = e^{2 \pi i/14}.$  We can identify $A$ with $2,$ $B$ with $-2,$ and $C_k$ with the complex number $2 \omega^k.$ [asy] unitsize (3 cm); int i; pair A, B; pair[] C; A = (1,0); B = (-1,0); C[1] = dir(1*180/7);
 C[2] = dir(2*180/7); C[3] = dir(3*180/7); C[4] = dir(4*180/7); C[5] = dir(5*180/7); C[6] = dir(6*180/7); draw(A--B); draw(arc((0,0),1,0,180)); for (i = 1; i <= 6; ++i) {   draw(A--C[i]--B);   dot("$C_" + string(i) + "$", C[i], C[i]);
 } dot("$A$", A, E); dot("$B$", B, W); [/asy] Then $AC_k = |2 - 2 \omega^k| = 2 |1 - \omega^k|$ and \[BC_k = |-2 - 2 \omega_k| = 2 |1 + \omega^k|.\]Since $\omega^7 = -1,$ we can also write this as \[BC_k = 2 |1 - \omega^{k + 7}|.\]Therefore, \[AC_1 \cdot AC_2 \dotsm AC_6 = 2^6 |(1 - \omega)(1 - \omega^2) \dotsm (1 - \omega^6)|\]and
 \[BC_1 \cdot BC_2 \dotsm BC_6 = 2^6 |(1 - \omega^8)(1 - \omega^9) \dotsm (1 - \omega^{13})|.\]Note that 1, $\omega,$ $\omega^2,$ $\dots,$ $\omega^{13}$ are all roots of $z^{14} - 1 = 0.$  Thus \[z^{14} - 1 = (z - 1)(z - \omega)(z - \omega^2) \dotsm (z - \omega^{13}).\]One factor on the right is $z - 1,$ and another factor on the right is $z - \omega^7 = z + 1.$  Thus, \[z^{14} - 1 = (z - 1)(z + 1) \cdot (z - \omega)(z - \omega^2) \dotsm (z - \omega^6)(z - \omega^8)(z - \omega^9) \dotsm (z - \omega^{13}).\]Since $z^{14} - 1 = (z^2 - 1)(z^{12} + z^{10} + z^8 + \dots + 1),$ we can write
 \[z^{12} + z^{10} + z^8 + \dots + 1 = (z - \omega)(z - \omega^2) \dotsm (z - \omega^6)(z - \omega^8)(z - \omega^9) \dotsm (z - \omega^{13}).\]Setting $z = 1,$ we get \[7 = (1 - \omega)(1 - \omega^2) \dotsm (1 - \omega^6)(1 - \omega^8)(1 - \omega^9) \dotsm (1 - \omega^{13}).\]Therefore, \begin{align}
 &AC_1 \cdot AC_2 \dotsm AC_6 \cdot BC_1 \cdot BC_2 \dotsm BC_6 \\ &= 2^6 |(1 - \omega)(1 - \omega^2) \dotsm (1 - \omega^6)| \cdot 2^6 |(1 - \omega^8)(1 - \omega^9) \dotsm (1 - \omega^{13})| \\ &= 2^{12} |(1 - \omega)(1 - \omega^2) \dotsm (1 - \omega^6)(1 - \omega^8)(1 - \omega^9) \dotsm (1 - \omega^{13})| \\
 &= 7 \cdot 2^{12} \\ &= \boxed{28672}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes A B :: "real * real" and C :: "int \<Rightarrow> real * real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 6 \<Longrightarrow> dist A (C i) = dist B (C i) = 2"
and h1 : "\<forall>i j. 1 \<le> i \<and> i < j \<and> j \<le> 6 \<Longrightarrow> dist (C i) (C j) = 2 * sin (pi / 7)"
and h2 : "dist A B = 2 * sqrt 2"
shows  "product (\<lambda>i. dist A (C i) * dist B (C i)) {1..6} = 28672"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem:
Let A and B be two points in a plane, and let C(i) be a function that maps an integer i to a point in the plane. Given that:
1. For every integer i between 1 and 6 inclusive, the distances from A to C(i) and from B to C(i) are both 2.
2. For every pair of distinct integers i, j between 1 and 6 inclusive, the distance between C(i) and C(j) equals 2 times the sine of pi/7.
3. The distance between A and B equals 2 times the square root of 2.

Find the product of all values of the distance from A to C(i) times the distance from B to C(i), where i ranges from 1 to 6. The final answer is 28672.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
and r :: real
and chord :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "A 1 = 0"
and h1 : "B 1 = 0"
and h2 : "r = 2"
and h3 : "\<forall> i \<in> {1..6}. C i = r * cos ((2 * pi * i) / 7)"
and h4 : "\<forall> i \<in> {1..6}. chord (A i) (C i) = sqrt (r powr 2 - (C i) powr 2)"
and h5 : "\<forall> i \<in> {1..6}. chord (B i) (C i) = sqrt (r powr 2 - (C i) powr 2)"
shows  "prod (chord (A i)) (i = 1..6) * prod (chord (B i)) (i = 1..6) = 28672"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $A$ and $B$ be the endpoints of a semicircular arc of radius $2$. The arc is divided into seven congruent arcs by six equally spaced points $C_1$, $C_2$, $\dots$, $C_6$. All chords of the form $\overline {AC_i}$ or $\overline {BC_i}$ are drawn. Find the product of the lengths of these twelve chords. The final Answer is 28672
 ### Proof
 Let $\omega = e^{2 \pi i/14}.$  We can identify $A$ with $2,$ $B$ with $-2,$ and $C_k$ with the complex number $2 \omega^k.$ [asy] unitsize (3 cm); int i; pair A, B; pair[] C; A = (1,0); B = (-1,0); C[1] = dir(1*180/7);
 C[2] = dir(2*180/7); C[3] = dir(3*180/7); C[4] = dir(4*180/7); C[5] = dir(5*180/7); C[6] = dir(6*180/7); draw(A--B); draw(arc((0,0),1,0,180)); for (i = 1; i <= 6; ++i) {   draw(A--C[i]--B);   dot("$C_" + string(i) + "$", C[i], C[i]);
 } dot("$A$", A, E); dot("$B$", B, W); [/asy] Then $AC_k = |2 - 2 \omega^k| = 2 |1 - \omega^k|$ and \[BC_k = |-2 - 2 \omega_k| = 2 |1 + \omega^k|.\]Since $\omega^7 = -1,$ we can also write this as \[BC_k = 2 |1 - \omega^{k + 7}|.\]Therefore, \[AC_1 \cdot AC_2 \dotsm AC_6 = 2^6 |(1 - \omega)(1 - \omega^2) \dotsm (1 - \omega^6)|\]and
 \[BC_1 \cdot BC_2 \dotsm BC_6 = 2^6 |(1 - \omega^8)(1 - \omega^9) \dotsm (1 - \omega^{13})|.\]Note that 1, $\omega,$ $\omega^2,$ $\dots,$ $\omega^{13}$ are all roots of $z^{14} - 1 = 0.$  Thus \[z^{14} - 1 = (z - 1)(z - \omega)(z - \omega^2) \dotsm (z - \omega^{13}).\]One factor on the right is $z - 1,$ and another factor on the right is $z - \omega^7 = z + 1.$  Thus, \[z^{14} - 1 = (z - 1)(z + 1) \cdot (z - \omega)(z - \omega^2) \dotsm (z - \omega^6)(z - \omega^8)(z - \omega^9) \dotsm (z - \omega^{13}).\]Since $z^{14} - 1 = (z^2 - 1)(z^{12} + z^{10} + z^8 + \dots + 1),$ we can write
 \[z^{12} + z^{10} + z^8 + \dots + 1 = (z - \omega)(z - \omega^2) \dotsm (z - \omega^6)(z - \omega^8)(z - \omega^9) \dotsm (z - \omega^{13}).\]Setting $z = 1,$ we get \[7 = (1 - \omega)(1 - \omega^2) \dotsm (1 - \omega^6)(1 - \omega^8)(1 - \omega^9) \dotsm (1 - \omega^{13}).\]Therefore, \begin{align}
 &AC_1 \cdot AC_2 \dotsm AC_6 \cdot BC_1 \cdot BC_2 \dotsm BC_6 \\ &= 2^6 |(1 - \omega)(1 - \omega^2) \dotsm (1 - \omega^6)| \cdot 2^6 |(1 - \omega^8)(1 - \omega^9) \dotsm (1 - \omega^{13})| \\ &= 2^{12} |(1 - \omega)(1 - \omega^2) \dotsm (1 - \omega^6)(1 - \omega^8)(1 - \omega^9) \dotsm (1 - \omega^{13})| \\
 &= 7 \cdot 2^{12} \\ &= \boxed{28672}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
and r :: real
and chord :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "A 1 = 0"
and h1 : "B 1 = 0"
and h2 : "r = 2"
and h3 : "\<forall> i \<in> {1..6}. C i = r * cos ((2 * pi * i) / 7)"
and h4 : "\<forall> i \<in> {1..6}. chord (A i) (C i) = sqrt (r powr 2 - (C i) powr 2)"
and h5 : "\<forall> i \<in> {1..6}. chord (B i) (C i) = sqrt (r powr 2 - (C i) powr 2)"
shows  "prod (chord (A i)) (i = 1..6) * prod (chord (B i)) (i = 1..6) = 28672"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: In a circle of radius 2, for each i in the set {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}, let A(i) = 0, B(i) = 0, and C(i) be the point on the circumference of the circle given by 2*cos(2πi/7). Define a function "chord" such that for any two points, the chord between them is given by the square root of the difference of the square of the radius and the square of the point on the circumference. Find the product of the lengths of all the chords from A(i) to C(i) and the product of all the chords from B(i) to C(i) for i from 1 to 6. The final result is 28672.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "A x = 2 * cos x"
and h1 : "B x = 2 * sin x"
and h2 : "\<forall> i. i \<ge> 1 \<and> i \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> C i = 2 * cos(i * pi / 7)"
and h3 : "\<forall> i. i \<ge> 1 \<and> i \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> dist (A x, C i) = dist (B x, C i)"
shows  "prod (\<lambda> i. dist (A x, C i) * dist (B x, C i)) {1..6} = 28672"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $A$ and $B$ be the endpoints of a semicircular arc of radius $2$. The arc is divided into seven congruent arcs by six equally spaced points $C_1$, $C_2$, $\dots$, $C_6$. All chords of the form $\overline {AC_i}$ or $\overline {BC_i}$ are drawn. Find the product of the lengths of these twelve chords. The final Answer is 28672
 ### Proof
 Let $\omega = e^{2 \pi i/14}.$  We can identify $A$ with $2,$ $B$ with $-2,$ and $C_k$ with the complex number $2 \omega^k.$ [asy] unitsize (3 cm); int i; pair A, B; pair[] C; A = (1,0); B = (-1,0); C[1] = dir(1*180/7);
 C[2] = dir(2*180/7); C[3] = dir(3*180/7); C[4] = dir(4*180/7); C[5] = dir(5*180/7); C[6] = dir(6*180/7); draw(A--B); draw(arc((0,0),1,0,180)); for (i = 1; i <= 6; ++i) {   draw(A--C[i]--B);   dot("$C_" + string(i) + "$", C[i], C[i]);
 } dot("$A$", A, E); dot("$B$", B, W); [/asy] Then $AC_k = |2 - 2 \omega^k| = 2 |1 - \omega^k|$ and \[BC_k = |-2 - 2 \omega_k| = 2 |1 + \omega^k|.\]Since $\omega^7 = -1,$ we can also write this as \[BC_k = 2 |1 - \omega^{k + 7}|.\]Therefore, \[AC_1 \cdot AC_2 \dotsm AC_6 = 2^6 |(1 - \omega)(1 - \omega^2) \dotsm (1 - \omega^6)|\]and
 \[BC_1 \cdot BC_2 \dotsm BC_6 = 2^6 |(1 - \omega^8)(1 - \omega^9) \dotsm (1 - \omega^{13})|.\]Note that 1, $\omega,$ $\omega^2,$ $\dots,$ $\omega^{13}$ are all roots of $z^{14} - 1 = 0.$  Thus \[z^{14} - 1 = (z - 1)(z - \omega)(z - \omega^2) \dotsm (z - \omega^{13}).\]One factor on the right is $z - 1,$ and another factor on the right is $z - \omega^7 = z + 1.$  Thus, \[z^{14} - 1 = (z - 1)(z + 1) \cdot (z - \omega)(z - \omega^2) \dotsm (z - \omega^6)(z - \omega^8)(z - \omega^9) \dotsm (z - \omega^{13}).\]Since $z^{14} - 1 = (z^2 - 1)(z^{12} + z^{10} + z^8 + \dots + 1),$ we can write
 \[z^{12} + z^{10} + z^8 + \dots + 1 = (z - \omega)(z - \omega^2) \dotsm (z - \omega^6)(z - \omega^8)(z - \omega^9) \dotsm (z - \omega^{13}).\]Setting $z = 1,$ we get \[7 = (1 - \omega)(1 - \omega^2) \dotsm (1 - \omega^6)(1 - \omega^8)(1 - \omega^9) \dotsm (1 - \omega^{13}).\]Therefore, \begin{align}
 &AC_1 \cdot AC_2 \dotsm AC_6 \cdot BC_1 \cdot BC_2 \dotsm BC_6 \\ &= 2^6 |(1 - \omega)(1 - \omega^2) \dotsm (1 - \omega^6)| \cdot 2^6 |(1 - \omega^8)(1 - \omega^9) \dotsm (1 - \omega^{13})| \\ &= 2^{12} |(1 - \omega)(1 - \omega^2) \dotsm (1 - \omega^6)(1 - \omega^8)(1 - \omega^9) \dotsm (1 - \omega^{13})| \\
 &= 7 \cdot 2^{12} \\ &= \boxed{28672}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "A x = 2 * cos x"
and h1 : "B x = 2 * sin x"
and h2 : "\<forall> i. i \<ge> 1 \<and> i \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> C i = 2 * cos(i * pi / 7)"
and h3 : "\<forall> i. i \<ge> 1 \<and> i \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> dist (A x, C i) = dist (B x, C i)"
shows  "prod (\<lambda> i. dist (A x, C i) * dist (B x, C i)) {1..6} = 28672"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Given three functions $A$, $B$, and $C$, where $A(x) = 2 \cos x$, $B(x) = 2 \sin x$, and $C(i) = 2 \cos(\frac{i \pi}{7})$ for $1 \leq i \leq 6$. If the distance from $A(x)$ to $C(i)$ is equal to the distance from $B(x)$ to $C(i)$ for $1 \leq i \leq 6$, what is the product of these distances for all $i$ from 1 to 6? The final answer is 28672.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
and r :: real
assumes h0 : "r = 2"
and h1 : "\<forall>i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> dist (A i) (C i) = dist (B i) (C i) = 2 * sin (pi / 14 * i)"
shows  "prod (\<lambda>i. dist (A i) (C i) * dist (B i) (C i)) {1..6} = 28672"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $A$ and $B$ be the endpoints of a semicircular arc of radius $2$. The arc is divided into seven congruent arcs by six equally spaced points $C_1$, $C_2$, $\dots$, $C_6$. All chords of the form $\overline {AC_i}$ or $\overline {BC_i}$ are drawn. Find the product of the lengths of these twelve chords. The final Answer is 28672
 ### Proof
 Let $\omega = e^{2 \pi i/14}.$  We can identify $A$ with $2,$ $B$ with $-2,$ and $C_k$ with the complex number $2 \omega^k.$ [asy] unitsize (3 cm); int i; pair A, B; pair[] C; A = (1,0); B = (-1,0); C[1] = dir(1*180/7);
 C[2] = dir(2*180/7); C[3] = dir(3*180/7); C[4] = dir(4*180/7); C[5] = dir(5*180/7); C[6] = dir(6*180/7); draw(A--B); draw(arc((0,0),1,0,180)); for (i = 1; i <= 6; ++i) {   draw(A--C[i]--B);   dot("$C_" + string(i) + "$", C[i], C[i]);
 } dot("$A$", A, E); dot("$B$", B, W); [/asy] Then $AC_k = |2 - 2 \omega^k| = 2 |1 - \omega^k|$ and \[BC_k = |-2 - 2 \omega_k| = 2 |1 + \omega^k|.\]Since $\omega^7 = -1,$ we can also write this as \[BC_k = 2 |1 - \omega^{k + 7}|.\]Therefore, \[AC_1 \cdot AC_2 \dotsm AC_6 = 2^6 |(1 - \omega)(1 - \omega^2) \dotsm (1 - \omega^6)|\]and
 \[BC_1 \cdot BC_2 \dotsm BC_6 = 2^6 |(1 - \omega^8)(1 - \omega^9) \dotsm (1 - \omega^{13})|.\]Note that 1, $\omega,$ $\omega^2,$ $\dots,$ $\omega^{13}$ are all roots of $z^{14} - 1 = 0.$  Thus \[z^{14} - 1 = (z - 1)(z - \omega)(z - \omega^2) \dotsm (z - \omega^{13}).\]One factor on the right is $z - 1,$ and another factor on the right is $z - \omega^7 = z + 1.$  Thus, \[z^{14} - 1 = (z - 1)(z + 1) \cdot (z - \omega)(z - \omega^2) \dotsm (z - \omega^6)(z - \omega^8)(z - \omega^9) \dotsm (z - \omega^{13}).\]Since $z^{14} - 1 = (z^2 - 1)(z^{12} + z^{10} + z^8 + \dots + 1),$ we can write
 \[z^{12} + z^{10} + z^8 + \dots + 1 = (z - \omega)(z - \omega^2) \dotsm (z - \omega^6)(z - \omega^8)(z - \omega^9) \dotsm (z - \omega^{13}).\]Setting $z = 1,$ we get \[7 = (1 - \omega)(1 - \omega^2) \dotsm (1 - \omega^6)(1 - \omega^8)(1 - \omega^9) \dotsm (1 - \omega^{13}).\]Therefore, \begin{align}
 &AC_1 \cdot AC_2 \dotsm AC_6 \cdot BC_1 \cdot BC_2 \dotsm BC_6 \\ &= 2^6 |(1 - \omega)(1 - \omega^2) \dotsm (1 - \omega^6)| \cdot 2^6 |(1 - \omega^8)(1 - \omega^9) \dotsm (1 - \omega^{13})| \\ &= 2^{12} |(1 - \omega)(1 - \omega^2) \dotsm (1 - \omega^6)(1 - \omega^8)(1 - \omega^9) \dotsm (1 - \omega^{13})| \\
 &= 7 \cdot 2^{12} \\ &= \boxed{28672}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
and r :: real
assumes h0 : "r = 2"
and h1 : "\<forall>i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> dist (A i) (C i) = dist (B i) (C i) = 2 * sin (pi / 14 * i)"
shows  "prod (\<lambda>i. dist (A i) (C i) * dist (B i) (C i)) {1..6} = 28672"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Given a set of points A, B, and C where the distance from A to C and B to C for each point i in the range from 1 to 6 is equal to $2 \sin (\frac{\pi}{14} \times i)$. Calculate the product of the distances between A to C and B to C for each of these points. The final answer is 28672.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B Ci :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
and r :: real
assumes h0 : "r = 2"
and h1 : "\<forall>i. i \<in> {1..6} \<longrightarrow> Ci i \<in> midpoint A B \<and> dist A (Ci i) = dist B (Ci i) = r / 7"
and h2 : "\<forall>i. i \<in> {1..6} \<longrightarrow> dist A (Ci i) = dist B (Ci i)"
shows  "prod (\<lambda>i. dist A (Ci i) * dist B (Ci i)) {1..6} = 28672"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $A$ and $B$ be the endpoints of a semicircular arc of radius $2$. The arc is divided into seven congruent arcs by six equally spaced points $C_1$, $C_2$, $\dots$, $C_6$. All chords of the form $\overline {AC_i}$ or $\overline {BC_i}$ are drawn. Find the product of the lengths of these twelve chords. The final Answer is 28672
 ### Proof
 Let $\omega = e^{2 \pi i/14}.$  We can identify $A$ with $2,$ $B$ with $-2,$ and $C_k$ with the complex number $2 \omega^k.$ [asy] unitsize (3 cm); int i; pair A, B; pair[] C; A = (1,0); B = (-1,0); C[1] = dir(1*180/7);
 C[2] = dir(2*180/7); C[3] = dir(3*180/7); C[4] = dir(4*180/7); C[5] = dir(5*180/7); C[6] = dir(6*180/7); draw(A--B); draw(arc((0,0),1,0,180)); for (i = 1; i <= 6; ++i) {   draw(A--C[i]--B);   dot("$C_" + string(i) + "$", C[i], C[i]);
 } dot("$A$", A, E); dot("$B$", B, W); [/asy] Then $AC_k = |2 - 2 \omega^k| = 2 |1 - \omega^k|$ and \[BC_k = |-2 - 2 \omega_k| = 2 |1 + \omega^k|.\]Since $\omega^7 = -1,$ we can also write this as \[BC_k = 2 |1 - \omega^{k + 7}|.\]Therefore, \[AC_1 \cdot AC_2 \dotsm AC_6 = 2^6 |(1 - \omega)(1 - \omega^2) \dotsm (1 - \omega^6)|\]and
 \[BC_1 \cdot BC_2 \dotsm BC_6 = 2^6 |(1 - \omega^8)(1 - \omega^9) \dotsm (1 - \omega^{13})|.\]Note that 1, $\omega,$ $\omega^2,$ $\dots,$ $\omega^{13}$ are all roots of $z^{14} - 1 = 0.$  Thus \[z^{14} - 1 = (z - 1)(z - \omega)(z - \omega^2) \dotsm (z - \omega^{13}).\]One factor on the right is $z - 1,$ and another factor on the right is $z - \omega^7 = z + 1.$  Thus, \[z^{14} - 1 = (z - 1)(z + 1) \cdot (z - \omega)(z - \omega^2) \dotsm (z - \omega^6)(z - \omega^8)(z - \omega^9) \dotsm (z - \omega^{13}).\]Since $z^{14} - 1 = (z^2 - 1)(z^{12} + z^{10} + z^8 + \dots + 1),$ we can write
 \[z^{12} + z^{10} + z^8 + \dots + 1 = (z - \omega)(z - \omega^2) \dotsm (z - \omega^6)(z - \omega^8)(z - \omega^9) \dotsm (z - \omega^{13}).\]Setting $z = 1,$ we get \[7 = (1 - \omega)(1 - \omega^2) \dotsm (1 - \omega^6)(1 - \omega^8)(1 - \omega^9) \dotsm (1 - \omega^{13}).\]Therefore, \begin{align}
 &AC_1 \cdot AC_2 \dotsm AC_6 \cdot BC_1 \cdot BC_2 \dotsm BC_6 \\ &= 2^6 |(1 - \omega)(1 - \omega^2) \dotsm (1 - \omega^6)| \cdot 2^6 |(1 - \omega^8)(1 - \omega^9) \dotsm (1 - \omega^{13})| \\ &= 2^{12} |(1 - \omega)(1 - \omega^2) \dotsm (1 - \omega^6)(1 - \omega^8)(1 - \omega^9) \dotsm (1 - \omega^{13})| \\
 &= 7 \cdot 2^{12} \\ &= \boxed{28672}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes A B Ci :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
and r :: real
assumes h0 : "r = 2"
and h1 : "\<forall>i. i \<in> {1..6} \<longrightarrow> Ci i \<in> midpoint A B \<and> dist A (Ci i) = dist B (Ci i) = r / 7"
and h2 : "\<forall>i. i \<in> {1..6} \<longrightarrow> dist A (Ci i) = dist B (Ci i)"
shows  "prod (\<lambda>i. dist A (Ci i) * dist B (Ci i)) {1..6} = 28672"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Consider six points $C_1, C_2, ..., C_6$ in the plane, each of which is equidistant from two fixed points $A$ and $B$ and lies on the line segment connecting $A$ and $B$. The distance from each point $C_i$ to $A$ and $B$ is $\frac{2}{7}$. Find the product of the distances from $A$ and $B$ to each of the points $C_i$ for $i$ in the set $\{1,2,3,4,5,6\}$. The final answer is 28672.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
and r :: real
assumes h0 : "A 1 = 2"
and h1 : "B 1 = 2"
and h2 : "r = 2"
and h3 : "\<forall> i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> C i = (A i + B i) / 2"
and h4 : "\<forall> i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> sqrt ((A i - C i) powr 2 + (B i - C i) powr 2) = r"
shows  "(\<Prod> i = 1..6. sqrt ((A i - C i) powr 2 + (B i - C i) powr 2)) = 28672"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $A$ and $B$ be the endpoints of a semicircular arc of radius $2$. The arc is divided into seven congruent arcs by six equally spaced points $C_1$, $C_2$, $\dots$, $C_6$. All chords of the form $\overline {AC_i}$ or $\overline {BC_i}$ are drawn. Find the product of the lengths of these twelve chords. The final Answer is 28672
 ### Proof
 Let $\omega = e^{2 \pi i/14}.$  We can identify $A$ with $2,$ $B$ with $-2,$ and $C_k$ with the complex number $2 \omega^k.$ [asy] unitsize (3 cm); int i; pair A, B; pair[] C; A = (1,0); B = (-1,0); C[1] = dir(1*180/7);
 C[2] = dir(2*180/7); C[3] = dir(3*180/7); C[4] = dir(4*180/7); C[5] = dir(5*180/7); C[6] = dir(6*180/7); draw(A--B); draw(arc((0,0),1,0,180)); for (i = 1; i <= 6; ++i) {   draw(A--C[i]--B);   dot("$C_" + string(i) + "$", C[i], C[i]);
 } dot("$A$", A, E); dot("$B$", B, W); [/asy] Then $AC_k = |2 - 2 \omega^k| = 2 |1 - \omega^k|$ and \[BC_k = |-2 - 2 \omega_k| = 2 |1 + \omega^k|.\]Since $\omega^7 = -1,$ we can also write this as \[BC_k = 2 |1 - \omega^{k + 7}|.\]Therefore, \[AC_1 \cdot AC_2 \dotsm AC_6 = 2^6 |(1 - \omega)(1 - \omega^2) \dotsm (1 - \omega^6)|\]and
 \[BC_1 \cdot BC_2 \dotsm BC_6 = 2^6 |(1 - \omega^8)(1 - \omega^9) \dotsm (1 - \omega^{13})|.\]Note that 1, $\omega,$ $\omega^2,$ $\dots,$ $\omega^{13}$ are all roots of $z^{14} - 1 = 0.$  Thus \[z^{14} - 1 = (z - 1)(z - \omega)(z - \omega^2) \dotsm (z - \omega^{13}).\]One factor on the right is $z - 1,$ and another factor on the right is $z - \omega^7 = z + 1.$  Thus, \[z^{14} - 1 = (z - 1)(z + 1) \cdot (z - \omega)(z - \omega^2) \dotsm (z - \omega^6)(z - \omega^8)(z - \omega^9) \dotsm (z - \omega^{13}).\]Since $z^{14} - 1 = (z^2 - 1)(z^{12} + z^{10} + z^8 + \dots + 1),$ we can write
 \[z^{12} + z^{10} + z^8 + \dots + 1 = (z - \omega)(z - \omega^2) \dotsm (z - \omega^6)(z - \omega^8)(z - \omega^9) \dotsm (z - \omega^{13}).\]Setting $z = 1,$ we get \[7 = (1 - \omega)(1 - \omega^2) \dotsm (1 - \omega^6)(1 - \omega^8)(1 - \omega^9) \dotsm (1 - \omega^{13}).\]Therefore, \begin{align}
 &AC_1 \cdot AC_2 \dotsm AC_6 \cdot BC_1 \cdot BC_2 \dotsm BC_6 \\ &= 2^6 |(1 - \omega)(1 - \omega^2) \dotsm (1 - \omega^6)| \cdot 2^6 |(1 - \omega^8)(1 - \omega^9) \dotsm (1 - \omega^{13})| \\ &= 2^{12} |(1 - \omega)(1 - \omega^2) \dotsm (1 - \omega^6)(1 - \omega^8)(1 - \omega^9) \dotsm (1 - \omega^{13})| \\
 &= 7 \cdot 2^{12} \\ &= \boxed{28672}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
and r :: real
assumes h0 : "A 1 = 2"
and h1 : "B 1 = 2"
and h2 : "r = 2"
and h3 : "\<forall> i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> C i = (A i + B i) / 2"
and h4 : "\<forall> i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> sqrt ((A i - C i) powr 2 + (B i - C i) powr 2) = r"
shows  "(\<Prod> i = 1..6. sqrt ((A i - C i) powr 2 + (B i - C i) powr 2)) = 28672"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Given two functions A and B such that A(1) = 2 and B(1) = 2, and a real number r = 2. We define a third function C such that for every integer i between 1 and 6 (inclusive), C(i) equals the average of A(i) and B(i). Also, for these values of i, the Euclidean distance between the points (A(i), B(i)) and (C(i), C(i)) is r. The problem is to calculate the product of these distances for i from 1 to 6. The final answer is 28672.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B Ci :: "real \<times> real"
and r :: real
and chords :: "real list"
assumes h0 : "r = 2"
and h1 : "arc A B r is_divided_by Ci for i in {1..6}"
and h2 : "chords = [dist A Ci | i <- {1..6}] @ [dist B Ci | i <- {1..6}]"
and h3 : "all_equal [arc A Ci r | i <- {1..6}]"
shows  "prod_list chords = 28672"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $A$ and $B$ be the endpoints of a semicircular arc of radius $2$. The arc is divided into seven congruent arcs by six equally spaced points $C_1$, $C_2$, $\dots$, $C_6$. All chords of the form $\overline {AC_i}$ or $\overline {BC_i}$ are drawn. Find the product of the lengths of these twelve chords. The final Answer is 28672
 ### Proof
 Let $\omega = e^{2 \pi i/14}.$  We can identify $A$ with $2,$ $B$ with $-2,$ and $C_k$ with the complex number $2 \omega^k.$ [asy] unitsize (3 cm); int i; pair A, B; pair[] C; A = (1,0); B = (-1,0); C[1] = dir(1*180/7);
 C[2] = dir(2*180/7); C[3] = dir(3*180/7); C[4] = dir(4*180/7); C[5] = dir(5*180/7); C[6] = dir(6*180/7); draw(A--B); draw(arc((0,0),1,0,180)); for (i = 1; i <= 6; ++i) {   draw(A--C[i]--B);   dot("$C_" + string(i) + "$", C[i], C[i]);
 } dot("$A$", A, E); dot("$B$", B, W); [/asy] Then $AC_k = |2 - 2 \omega^k| = 2 |1 - \omega^k|$ and \[BC_k = |-2 - 2 \omega_k| = 2 |1 + \omega^k|.\]Since $\omega^7 = -1,$ we can also write this as \[BC_k = 2 |1 - \omega^{k + 7}|.\]Therefore, \[AC_1 \cdot AC_2 \dotsm AC_6 = 2^6 |(1 - \omega)(1 - \omega^2) \dotsm (1 - \omega^6)|\]and
 \[BC_1 \cdot BC_2 \dotsm BC_6 = 2^6 |(1 - \omega^8)(1 - \omega^9) \dotsm (1 - \omega^{13})|.\]Note that 1, $\omega,$ $\omega^2,$ $\dots,$ $\omega^{13}$ are all roots of $z^{14} - 1 = 0.$  Thus \[z^{14} - 1 = (z - 1)(z - \omega)(z - \omega^2) \dotsm (z - \omega^{13}).\]One factor on the right is $z - 1,$ and another factor on the right is $z - \omega^7 = z + 1.$  Thus, \[z^{14} - 1 = (z - 1)(z + 1) \cdot (z - \omega)(z - \omega^2) \dotsm (z - \omega^6)(z - \omega^8)(z - \omega^9) \dotsm (z - \omega^{13}).\]Since $z^{14} - 1 = (z^2 - 1)(z^{12} + z^{10} + z^8 + \dots + 1),$ we can write
 \[z^{12} + z^{10} + z^8 + \dots + 1 = (z - \omega)(z - \omega^2) \dotsm (z - \omega^6)(z - \omega^8)(z - \omega^9) \dotsm (z - \omega^{13}).\]Setting $z = 1,$ we get \[7 = (1 - \omega)(1 - \omega^2) \dotsm (1 - \omega^6)(1 - \omega^8)(1 - \omega^9) \dotsm (1 - \omega^{13}).\]Therefore, \begin{align}
 &AC_1 \cdot AC_2 \dotsm AC_6 \cdot BC_1 \cdot BC_2 \dotsm BC_6 \\ &= 2^6 |(1 - \omega)(1 - \omega^2) \dotsm (1 - \omega^6)| \cdot 2^6 |(1 - \omega^8)(1 - \omega^9) \dotsm (1 - \omega^{13})| \\ &= 2^{12} |(1 - \omega)(1 - \omega^2) \dotsm (1 - \omega^6)(1 - \omega^8)(1 - \omega^9) \dotsm (1 - \omega^{13})| \\
 &= 7 \cdot 2^{12} \\ &= \boxed{28672}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes A B Ci :: "real \<times> real"
and r :: real
and chords :: "real list"
assumes h0 : "r = 2"
and h1 : "arc A B r is_divided_by Ci for i in {1..6}"
and h2 : "chords = [dist A Ci | i <- {1..6}] @ [dist B Ci | i <- {1..6}]"
and h3 : "all_equal [arc A Ci r | i <- {1..6}]"
shows  "prod_list chords = 28672"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Given a circle with radius 2, an arc A-B is divided into six equal parts by points C1 through C6. If the "chords" list consists of the distances from A and B to each of the Ci points, and all the arcs from A to each Ci are equal, find the product of all elements in the "chords" list. The final answer is 28672.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B :: "real * real" 
and C :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real * real"
assumes h0 : "dist A B = 2 * pi"
and h1 : "\<forall> i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> dist A (C i) = dist B (C i) \<and> dist A (C i) = 2 * pi / 7 * i"
shows  "prod (\<lambda> i. dist A (C i) * dist B (C i)) {1..6} = 28672"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $A$ and $B$ be the endpoints of a semicircular arc of radius $2$. The arc is divided into seven congruent arcs by six equally spaced points $C_1$, $C_2$, $\dots$, $C_6$. All chords of the form $\overline {AC_i}$ or $\overline {BC_i}$ are drawn. Find the product of the lengths of these twelve chords. The final Answer is 28672
 ### Proof
 Let $\omega = e^{2 \pi i/14}.$  We can identify $A$ with $2,$ $B$ with $-2,$ and $C_k$ with the complex number $2 \omega^k.$ [asy] unitsize (3 cm); int i; pair A, B; pair[] C; A = (1,0); B = (-1,0); C[1] = dir(1*180/7);
 C[2] = dir(2*180/7); C[3] = dir(3*180/7); C[4] = dir(4*180/7); C[5] = dir(5*180/7); C[6] = dir(6*180/7); draw(A--B); draw(arc((0,0),1,0,180)); for (i = 1; i <= 6; ++i) {   draw(A--C[i]--B);   dot("$C_" + string(i) + "$", C[i], C[i]);
 } dot("$A$", A, E); dot("$B$", B, W); [/asy] Then $AC_k = |2 - 2 \omega^k| = 2 |1 - \omega^k|$ and \[BC_k = |-2 - 2 \omega_k| = 2 |1 + \omega^k|.\]Since $\omega^7 = -1,$ we can also write this as \[BC_k = 2 |1 - \omega^{k + 7}|.\]Therefore, \[AC_1 \cdot AC_2 \dotsm AC_6 = 2^6 |(1 - \omega)(1 - \omega^2) \dotsm (1 - \omega^6)|\]and
 \[BC_1 \cdot BC_2 \dotsm BC_6 = 2^6 |(1 - \omega^8)(1 - \omega^9) \dotsm (1 - \omega^{13})|.\]Note that 1, $\omega,$ $\omega^2,$ $\dots,$ $\omega^{13}$ are all roots of $z^{14} - 1 = 0.$  Thus \[z^{14} - 1 = (z - 1)(z - \omega)(z - \omega^2) \dotsm (z - \omega^{13}).\]One factor on the right is $z - 1,$ and another factor on the right is $z - \omega^7 = z + 1.$  Thus, \[z^{14} - 1 = (z - 1)(z + 1) \cdot (z - \omega)(z - \omega^2) \dotsm (z - \omega^6)(z - \omega^8)(z - \omega^9) \dotsm (z - \omega^{13}).\]Since $z^{14} - 1 = (z^2 - 1)(z^{12} + z^{10} + z^8 + \dots + 1),$ we can write
 \[z^{12} + z^{10} + z^8 + \dots + 1 = (z - \omega)(z - \omega^2) \dotsm (z - \omega^6)(z - \omega^8)(z - \omega^9) \dotsm (z - \omega^{13}).\]Setting $z = 1,$ we get \[7 = (1 - \omega)(1 - \omega^2) \dotsm (1 - \omega^6)(1 - \omega^8)(1 - \omega^9) \dotsm (1 - \omega^{13}).\]Therefore, \begin{align}
 &AC_1 \cdot AC_2 \dotsm AC_6 \cdot BC_1 \cdot BC_2 \dotsm BC_6 \\ &= 2^6 |(1 - \omega)(1 - \omega^2) \dotsm (1 - \omega^6)| \cdot 2^6 |(1 - \omega^8)(1 - \omega^9) \dotsm (1 - \omega^{13})| \\ &= 2^{12} |(1 - \omega)(1 - \omega^2) \dotsm (1 - \omega^6)(1 - \omega^8)(1 - \omega^9) \dotsm (1 - \omega^{13})| \\
 &= 7 \cdot 2^{12} \\ &= \boxed{28672}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes A B :: "real * real" 
and C :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real * real"
assumes h0 : "dist A B = 2 * pi"
and h1 : "\<forall> i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> dist A (C i) = dist B (C i) \<and> dist A (C i) = 2 * pi / 7 * i"
shows  "prod (\<lambda> i. dist A (C i) * dist B (C i)) {1..6} = 28672"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given a pair of points A and B in a two-dimensional real space such that the distance between them is $2\pi$. Also, there exists a function C that maps a natural number to a point in the same space. For all natural numbers i between 1 and 6 inclusive, the distance from A to C(i) is equal to the distance from B to C(i), and both are equal to $\frac{2\pi}{7}i$. Find the product of the distances between A and C(i) and between B and C(i) for all i from 1 to 6. The final answer is 28672.
